channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Majority of Minneapolis City Council Pledges to Dismantle Police Department
item.description: Some cities are starting to to heed calls to “defund the police,” as lawmakers push proposals for greater police accountability. National Guard troops are being sent home from Washington, D.C.
item.media:credit: Laylah Amatullah Barrayn for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Powderhorn Park in Minneapolis on Sunday called for the defunding of the city’s Police Department.

item.title: George Floyd Protests Add New Front Line for Coronavirus Doctors
item.description: Many physicians wish to show solidarity at the demonstrations, but some fear a second wave of infection will follow.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:description: Mount Sinai nurses and doctors cheered on protesters at Union Square in Manhattan on Tuesday.

item.title: Coronavirus Jumps the Border, Overwhelming Hospitals in California
item.description: Hospitals are airlifting patients to facilities hundreds of miles away to handle an influx of Americans and U.S. green card holders sickened in Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:description: A health care worker in protective gear treated a patient with the coronavirus at the El Centro Regional Medical Center in El Centro, Calif., last month.

item.title: Merriam-Webster Revises ‘Racism’ Entry After Missouri Woman Asks for Changes
item.description: Kennedy Mitchum, 22, said the dictionary definition needed to be expanded to include systemic racism. The dictionary’s editors agreed.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:credit: Christian Gooden/St. Louis Post-Dispatch, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kennedy Mitchum wrote to the editors of Merriam-Webster that racism was “prejudice combined with social and institutional power. It is a system of advantage based on skin color.”

item.title: George Floyd’s Brother Pleads With Congress: ‘Make it Stop’
item.description: Philonise Floyd, the star witness at a House hearing on Democrats’ policing bill, called for Congress to “stop the pain” caused by the killings of black men at the hands of police.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: “This is 2020,” Philonise Floyd said. “Enough is enough. The people marching in the streets are telling you enough is enough.”

item.title: For a Day, Scientists Pause Science to Confront Racism
item.description: Scholars said they would not hold classes or lectures on Wednesday, and leading journals and scientific associations said they would not announce most breakthroughs.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:description: Brian Nord, center, is a physicist at Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory. “We need to rethink what scientific collaborations should look like,” he said. “Black people need a seat at the table.”

item.title: The Army Was Open to Replacing Confederate Base Names. Then Trump Said No.
item.description: “My Administration will not even consider the renaming of these Magnificent and Fabled Military Installations,” President Trump tweeted Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Mark Esper and Army Secretary Ryan McCarthy said Monday that they are “open to a bipartisan discussion” of renaming Army bases like North Carolina’s Fort Bragg that are named after Confederate officers.

item.title: Christopher Columbus Statues in Boston and Virginia Are Damaged
item.description: The incidents, in Boston’s North End and Richmond, Va., came as protesters angered by the death of George Floyd have targeted monuments that they see as symbols of white supremacy.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: A statue of Christopher Columbus in Christopher Columbus Park in Boston on Wednesday. Mayor Marty Walsh said the statue would be stored while its fate was discussed.

item.title: White House Tells Bolton His Book Still Contains Classified Information
item.description: A White House official said Mr. Bolton would be given a redacted version of his manuscript by June 19, four days before the book’s current publication date.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: John R. Bolton’s book is a nearly 600-page account of his time working for President Trump from April 2018 until September 2019.

item.title: Michael Flynn Case a 'Gross Abuse' of Power, Says Former Federal Judge
item.description: A former federal judge said that the attorney general gave special treatment to a presidential ally, undermining public confidence in the rule of law.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Adam Goldman
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael Flynn pleaded guilty to lying to the F.B.I. in December 2017, but later backtracked.

item.title: Meet the ‘Grandmother of Street Medics’
item.description: Volunteers have provided first aid at protests since at least the 1960s. Many of them owe their training to Ann Hirschman.
item.dc:creator: Jonah Engel Bromwich
item.media:credit: Celeste Sloman for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the 1960s, Ann Hirschman became one of the earliest street medics: volunteers who attend protests to address any first aid needs that might arise.

item.title: Has Lindsey Graham Become Too Trumpy for South Carolina? Not So Fast
item.description: Democrats are mounting a vigorous Senate campaign, backing Jaime Harrison, a candidate with strong fund-raising. But as they argue that Mr. Graham has become too conservative for the state, the senator has gained supporters.
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times
item.media:description: Since fully embracing President Trump, Senator Lindsey Graham has become South Carolina’s most popular Republican official, internal state G.O.P. polling shows. He used to be one of the least popular.

item.title: Live Updates: George Floyd's Brother Testifies in House Hearing
item.description: The House Judiciary Committee is hearing testimony on police accountability. The fallout from protests is spreading across industries.

item.title: When Are Nail Salons Reopening in California?
item.description: Wednesday: The plight of manicurists shows how the pandemic is hurting immigrant communities. Also: More debates over policing; and Juneteenth.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:description: Nail shop owners and workers protested Monday in Westminster to demand that Gov. Gavin Newsom lift Covid-19 restrictions on nail salons. There are a variety of viewpoints, but many are seeking guidelines.

item.title: Republican Weighing New Convention Options as They Eye Move to Jacksonville
item.description: The Florida city has been Republicans’ top choice for days, after President Trump told officials in North Carolina that he did not want the convention to feature social distancing.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Annie Karni
item.media:description: Jacksonville is the most populous city in Florida, and its mayor is a longtime Republican official.

item.title: Georgia’s Election Descends Into Chaos
item.description: A dry run for November raises new questions about ballot access: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: Georgia’s Long Lines
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Voters waited in long lines in Atlanta on Tuesday.

item.title: Coronavirus Live Updates: Cases in the U.S. Top 2 Million and Are Rising in 21 States
item.description: The world economy is facing the most severe recession in a century. Oregon and other states have begun holding jury trials again, posing new challenges.
item.media:credit: Josh Ritchie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Luke Phillips, an employee at the Fontainebleau Miami Beach hotel on Sunday. The resort reopened this month, even as Florida saw persistent growth in coronavirus cases.

item.title: Fed Expects Unemployment Rate to Stay High: Live Updates
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:credit: Ting Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Federal Reserve indicated that it expected the unemployment rate to end 2020 at 9.3 percent and remain elevated for years.

item.title: HBO Max Pulls ‘Gone With the Wind,’ Citing Racist Depictions
item.description: The streaming service said it planned to eventually bring the 1939 film back “with a discussion of its historical context.”
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O’Hara and Hattie McDaniel as Mammy in “Gone With the Wind.” Ms. McDaniel became the first African-American to win an Oscar for the role.

item.title: 2020 Is the Summer of the Road Trip. Unless You’re Black.
item.description: The family road trip is making a comeback in the wake of the coronavirus, but for African-American motorists, it’s never been a source of unfettered freedom.
item.dc:creator: Tariro Mzezewa
item.media:description: A black family going for a drive in the 1960s.

item.title: An Arrest Warrant From Liberty University, for Me
item.description: Julia Rendleman, a freelance photographer for The New York Times, was accused of trespassing by the evangelical school run by Jerry Falwell Jr. in March.
item.dc:creator: Julia Rendleman
item.media:description: Julia Rendleman, a freelance photographer, briefly considered giving up journalism after being accused of trespassing.

item.title: A Black Vice President for Biden? More Democrats Are Making the Case
item.description: Amid a national reckoning over racism and police brutality, many Democrats have been increasingly vocal in urging that Joe Biden give deeper consideration to placing a black woman on the ticket.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. speaking with community leaders last week at a church in Wilmington, Del.

item.title: Threat of Military Action Rattles Brazil as Virus Deaths Surge
item.description: As Brazil reels from its worst crisis in decades, President Bolsonaro and his allies are using the prospect of military intervention to protect his grip on power.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero, Letícia Casado and Manuela Andreoni
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gravediggers in São Paulo. President Jair Bolsonaro brushed aside the threat of the coronavirus even as the number of people dying surged.

item.title: Stepfather of Missing Idaho Children Is Arrested After Human Remains Are Found
item.description: Chad Daybell, 51, an Idaho man whose former wife died under questionable circumstances, was charged with concealing evidence, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: National Center for Missing & Exploited Children, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The missing children, Joshua Vallow, left, and Tylee Ryan.

item.title: Jon Ossoff Holds Strong Lead as Georgia Waits for Senate Primary Results
item.description: After a day of chaotic voting, Mr. Ossoff, a 33-year-old Democrat, was well ahead but still facing the possibility of a runoff election for the opportunity to challenge Senator David Perdue.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset and Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters outside the Mary Lin and Candler Park combined precincts in Atlanta on Tuesday.

item.title: This Nurse is Leading the Fight for Safer Hospitals
item.description: Bonnie Castillo, head of National Nurses United, raised the alarm over shortages of personal protective equipment long before others recognized the scale of the pandemic. She’s still fighting.
item.dc:creator: Rikha Sharma Rani
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bonnie Castillo at her home in Sacramento.

item.title: Twitter and Square Make Juneteenth a Company Holiday
item.description: The day marks the anniversary of when slaves in Galveston, Texas, first learned of their freedom on June 19, 1865.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Yong Kim/The Philadelphia Inquirer, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Third Regiment United States Colored Troops re-enactors during the Juneteenth Parade and Festival in 2018 in Philadelphia.

item.title: Trump May Compare Himself to Nixon in 1968, but He Really Resembles Wallace
item.description: The president has employed the same kind of inflammatory language as George Wallace did in the 1968 campaign. Richard Nixon ran that year seeking the middle between the Alabama governor and Hubert Humphrey.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Trump’s approach has been compared to Richard M. Nixon’s law-and-order strategy.

item.title: G.O.P. Scrambles to Respond to Public Demands for Police Overhaul
item.description: Republicans have been startled by the extent to which public opinion has shifted in recent days after the killings of unarmed black Americans by the police and the protests that have followed.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson and Nicholas Fandos
item.media:description: Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina, the Republican Party’s lone black senator, was tasked with leading a group to craft a conservative policy response to calls for police reform.

item.title: Protests Reach Political Ads
item.description: Here’s how the presidential campaigns and other groups are using the mass protests in their political messaging.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti

item.title: That Trump Tweet? Republicans Prefer Not to See It
item.description: Even when presented with a printout of the president’s incendiary Twitter comment, Republicans toiled to avoid commenting.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:description: Senator Kevin Cramer, Republican of North Dakota, said on Tuesday that he did not know what President Trump was talking about when handed a printout of a tweet.

item.title: Many Have Antibodies After Coronavirus Outbreak on Carrier Roosevelt
item.description: A C.D.C. study found that some sailors showed protection against the coronavirus three months after the onset of symptoms.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Sailors with the U.S. Navy were screened for coronavirus symptoms before boarding the Theodore Roosevelt last month.

item.title: AMC Says ‘Almost All’ U.S. Theaters Will Reopen in July
item.description: The chain reported that it lost more than $2 billion in the most recent quarter, when the pandemic essentially stopped theatergoing.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.media:description: Seats will be sanitized between showtimes when theaters reopen, and employees will have to wear masks.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Five rules to help lower your risk of infection while still living a full life.
item.dc:creator: Lara Takenaga and Jonathan Wolfe
